I loved it! The city resize is a huge improvement and it makes everything feel more alive. The new gameplay dynamics are refreshing, and the story is great. The visuals and animations look amazing, and swinging through the city is still super fun.

On the downside, the game feels a bit short and the side missions get a little repetitive. I hope they improve that in the next game. Something I’d love is the ability to go inside the subway. That would be awesome. Also, there are only a few achievements and they’re not very challenging. It would be great to have more achievements or harder ones to unlock.

The Spider-Man games have been some of my favorite games to play on my Steam Deck! 

These are my personal favorite interpretations of Peter Parker, Mary Jane Watson, and Miles Morales.

The gameplay is slick and responsive, which is how I like to feel when playing a superhero game.

The story is heartbreaking and beautiful at the same time. You feel for All these characters as they have to grapple with responsibility and trying to not lose themselves. 

Also - hot take - I love the MJ side quests. I found them to be a nice break in between the constant fast paced action throughout the games. 

It provided insight into MJ's work and how even though she doesn't have powers, she's still just as much of a hero as Pete and Miles. 

My only complaint with Spider-Man 2 is it's hard to make it run well on my Steam Deck without lossless scaling. 

Not a deal breaker, just something people new to the games should be aware of. 

Overall! These games are great! Give them a chance and you won't regret it!

This is a hesitant recommendation. Only get it if you have a device strong enough to play it. On steam deck, it drops down to 15fps regularly, despite being "Verified." The game is quite fun otherwise.

[h2]Sequel Swings Higher Than Before[/h2]

Really enjoyed Marvel's Spider-Man 2, swinging as both Peter and Miles was pure fun with seamless switching between them. The removal of tedious crimes from the first game cuts down on repetition, and the side content feels solid and varied. [b]Tweaking with gadgets is heavily nerfed compared to previous Spider-Man games[/b], though still viable in combat. It’s a little sad there are no DLCs like the first game, [spoiler]but the hints teasing Carnage keep things exciting for the future.[/spoiler]

I only hit minor stutters with no major bugs on my setup, though a friend dealt with T-poses and characters breaking into weird poses. Overall, [b]it's a strong sequel with great traversal and combat that really nails the superhero vibe[/b]. [u]7/10 — worth it for fans.[/u] :D

Excellent game and great gaming experience. Visuals are absolutely superb and immersive, movement and combat are very fluid and satisfying to perform, cutscenes and action sequences both deliver an exceptional cinematic experience. The story is actually pretty great, and side missions are mostly interesting and worthwhile.

I can say this is the best game in the Marvel’s Spider-Man series. This time, being able to play both Peter and Miles adds a lot of variety to the game. The new symbiote powers, improved web-swinging, and more detailed combat system are really satisfying. Performance met my high expectations, optimization is good, and the city is bigger but still runs smoothly.
The story is perfect, it is very dramatic and full of action, and having control in these moments is amazing. Switching between the two characters keeps the gameplay fun and fresh, but I wish Peter and Miles had more interactions with each other.

This game genuinely captivated my wife and I like no other game has this year. It's been done to death, but you really do feel like Spider-Man. I wish the final act was more fleshed out, but for what we have, I loved it to bits. Venom was better in Spider-Man PSX, but it's hard to top perfection.. I still adored him, and it was a beautiful, emotional ride. Can't wait for Spider-Man 3!! Carnage & Green Goblin are gonna rock.

The last half of the story is more familiar spider-man lore with venom taking over the city and causing a rampage. Slightly better but very familiar already. Actually, i liked to play as Miles most as he was doing tasks for his neighborhood and community.

Spider-Man 2 is everything I wanted from a superhero game.
Insomniac refined the formula to a point where swinging through the city feels almost meditative — smooth, fast and incredibly satisfying. The combat kept the rhythm of the previous title but added just enough depth and variety to stay fresh the whole way through.

The story surprised me. It’s emotional without being cheesy, and both Peter and Miles have strong, distinct arcs. The pacing is tight, the set pieces are huge, and the performances are top-tier.

Visually, the game is stunning. The city is denser, more alive, and the transitions between cutscenes and gameplay are absurdly seamless. It’s one of those games where you stop mid-mission just to appreciate the skyline.

If you enjoyed the first game and Miles Morales, this one feels like a true evolution. Not perfect — a few side missions are hit-or-miss — but the highs are really high.

Easily one of the best superhero games ever made.

The game elevates everything that was fantastic about the earlier games. It feels faster, smoother, and more vibrant than ever to swing through New York. Both heroes have memorable moments thanks to the emotional, passionate, and well-balanced dual stories of Peter and Miles. It truly seems like a playable Spider-Man movie because of how exciting and heartfelt the Venom arc is. The world is rich and immersive, the combat is more dynamic, and the outfits are amazing. As a lifelong admirer of Spider-Man, I couldn't stop grinning at this game. It's the best Spider-Man experience, not merely a sequel. 5/5

What an amazing game in every way.

First the story. I heard a lot of people saying it would be subpar or worse than in SM1. I don't think that it's bad in anyway really. Liked it just as much as the SM1 story. It was really immersive and had lots of points where it made you emotionally attach to something. Lots of turning points and so on. I felt it was really good. 

Secondly the gameplay. It is very very smooth compared to SM1 and Miles Morales. The way the combat feels is great, traversal is great and the mechanics are great. The combat animations are so smooth and flowy.

And lastly the technical side which I would say is the only tiny minus to the game. The game is clearly not optimized well to pc. The game struggles to load things fast enough so when traversing through the city with speed the fps struggles to keep at 60 fps and sometimes there's a 1 second loading freeze before some cutscenes but I feel like that would be fixed with more and faster RAM as well as better CPU. Otherwise when not moving at great speeds and fighting the fps is there up in the hundreds in 2K resolution.

Overall the game is one of the best games I have ever played. I don't remember the last time I had a 12 hour gaming session without bigger breaks. The game just pulled me into the story so well.
Can't wait for the final chapter in SM3

If you like the first Marvel's Spider-Man game, this game has built upon a pretty solid foundation. The results are a better combat system, means of traversing around NYC, and enemy types. While Spider-Man 2 doesn't do anything genre-defining or subversive, what it does do is very well and you can see how much passion Insomniac Games pour into this game. I personally found the story of Spider-Man 1 to be better crafted than this title, however. It doesn't make Spider-Man 2's story less emotional and found that it had higher narrative beats especially with Miles Morales' struggles. However, I felt it was a lost opportunity to develop Harry and the symbiote, given how impactful they were, as Venom, to the story and the friction with the rest of the cast. 

I do like Dr. Octopus and the set of villains from the first game more than Karven from both a narrative, gameplay, and motivational perspective. However, I found Venom to be very imposing and I wished he had a bigger presence throughout the story, replacing Karven, rather towards the end. A feature I did not enjoy about both Spider-Man games is the gameplay segment with MJ and her stealth mission, as you really got to suspend your disbelief and it feels bad to go from playing as Peter and Miles to MJ. Overall, I had a great time with Marvel's Spider-Man 2, especially as a fan and give it a 8.5/10. For the price I paid for it, I definitely got what I paid for and would recommend it to anyone looking for a fun superhero game.

negative.review:
Gonna keep this short and sweet - Spider-Man 2 is not a bad game. It is stunning, fluid, crispy, and is a blast to play to embody the Friendly Neighborhood Spider-Man.
The problem is the optimization. I have a decently beefy Rig (RTX 4070ti) and I have not once been able to keep a stable frame rate, constant pop-ins, stutters. Swinging too fast will cause the game to pause and catch up the loading process. Raytracing is still busted, and will not work. Tanks the game's performance whereas other titles I have played utilizing Ray Tracing run perfectly fine with rarely any issue. 
Its not a bad game, but the optimization is pure cheeks. Until it properly gets fixed (which it probably never will), this review will remain negative.
If you have any optimization tips, let me know.

The writing is really rough, it asks you to suspend a lot of disbelief, but unfortunately it doesn't create an immersive environment suitable enough to allow you too. It doesn't help that there is just so much political messaging in the game too. Whether you agree with it or not, it being there for reasons other than story and gameplay is just constantly annoying and a part of why it's challenging to immerse yourself generally. It's a shame because the game feels and plays like a technical masterpiece otherwise. 

The game would be a lot more pallatable if the cutscenes were skippable but unfortunately I can't recommend sitting through the dialogue.

This game is not only dissapointing but very out of character in comparison to the other games in this franchise. From stupid gameplay changes to a slow paced story, this game is like getting socks for christmas.

My first 45 minutes in this game was figuring out the right settings because this game is insanely unoptimized. I read about it online and it's a big problem that even fulfilling system requirements does not save you from lags and many visual glitches. I literally had to google settings people made, to enjoy this game in a normal state but I still get frame loss during missions or on bigger maps. The AI upscaling made it even worse.
There are also so many bugs with character models in which they either get stuck or break certain animations. 

I kinda ignored these and tried to enjoy the game. 
I am here for the story, the cool fighting and other collectibles in the city. So I didn't cared that much.
But even this seemed too much to ask for because one tiny change, did so much damage for my experience personally.
Changing the healing was by far the most unnecessary change of all time. You can only heal with a full focusbar now. 

This is important because the fighting itself also kinda changed with the difficulty. Not only are there enemies which counter almost your entire arsenal, the snipers in this game shoot you faster and more often now. 
The healing change is basically causing you, to not have a real choice anymore for actual finishers because now the need to heal is much bigger now. So you just smash buttons till the whole bar is charged, which takes so much fkn time to do so.
This entire thing just changes everything in terms of getting throu the story because you changed the entire pace of the game. Either you just spam abilities till you're allowed to heal or just dodge and hope you get by the 500 snipers that change their position every second. 
Seriously, If Spider-Man can stop a moving car with his hands, why can't he punch throu a shield.

I love the last two games, even if it was becoming repetitiv in someway, you knew, you get to do stuff your way. Now your limited by the game itselft and you actually get annoyed when you have to fight. I just instantly knew, that backline enemies will snipe me to my death.
 I don't know why this was even necessary to change, the fighting worked so well in Spider-Man: Miles Morales and you just throw it away for the sake of being different. It feels like a major step in the opposite direction since Spider-Man: Miles Morales felt sharper and cleaner than the first game.

Now to the story
I am a huge believer that cutscenes are only important, if the intention is to convey information and plot. Anything other than that is just time wasted. Like when someone takes away your controller and you wait for your turn. The pacing in this game is really bad because the plot goes by so slow while the story missions itself change constantly between your gameplay and unskippable cutscene inbetween. They feel so shallow after some time because you just want to play and have fun while the game holds you back to show you something you forgot anyway.
The story had such a weak first act, I can't believe how much of a step back this seems. It want's to introduce so many character arcs, plot and story lines while failling to convey tension or emotions. I loved the last games for actually putting focus on a conflict instead of showing us so many potential conflicts in one first act.

I also couldn't give less of a shit for Kraven because he has the character depth of a puddle. At somepoint I just wanted to get done with it because the game just couldn't go by faster. 
We already know what his plan is but next to peter, you obviously have to change to miles now, because the game wants you to and have to play his character arc out which somehow has almost nothing to do with the main story. You get the feeling that nothing is happening, everything is stretching while you already know what Kraven wants, does and can do.
I asked myself so many times when I get to do peter missions again to finally progress with Kraven again.
It only got interesting for me when we actually got to see Venoms influence and himself in his form which in my opinion took way to long. Like we got actual plot progession and tension after more than 60% of the story done.
I was so shocked to see how cool this game can get after the whole boredom I had to endure. 

You have to build your story and characters up, I get that but let's be real, Kraven had almost no impact that was significant to the story.  It could've been any other villain and I blame the very little screentime he actually had in the game
He kills many people that could've had a potential comeback to the games but it was made very clear, that this was never the intention in the first place. 

Spider-Man 2 want's you to understand that it's better now, it's so cool and has so many cool new features but totally forgets what made it fun in the first place. The moment you rather play side missions than continue with the main story, is the moment you have to realize you failed. 
I loved getting to play this series but feeling so tired of this one just made me sad man. Not every new installment needs big and new changes. Especially with core gameplay mechanics.

Originally I wrote this review after dropping the game several hours in for many reasons but being a big Spider-Man fan I felt I had to at least give this game a proper try. I wish I didn't.
What's to say that hasn't already been said? Many issues about the game are well documented via other reviews and the many videos on YouTube but I still need to express just how bad the main plot is. There are elements of good moments but they're grains of sand on a Sandman. So many questionable choices. One big one being Miles.

Now before I continue, I'm biased. I don't like Miles, don't like how forced in Media he is, or his support group (except Rio, she's cool and Arron is alright) but he's the Rey Palpatine of MSM2. Peter is unable to do pretty much anything without Miles, even the personal battle of Spider-Man vs Venom, a fight which the narrative has made it a big point of it being about them and MJ, has Miles not only thrown into it, but saving Peter. Which by that point has become a pattern of bad writing. Of course we can't talk about the plot without mentioning Scream. Those who know, know. It's probably THE prime example of how bad the writing in this game is.
The biggest sin this game commits though is how badly they treat Peter. Parker luck is not only in full force but it's like he's wearing the Sonichu pendant too. If this Peter was in the first game, the helicopter scene would have resulted in a bloodbath. He's unable to do anything to the point where his greatest enemy in this game is a fridge (those who know) which doesn't make me angry, just depressed. What kind of tar do you have to have in your soul to hurt our boy Peter so bad?

As for the gameplay, I honestly feel traversal is downgraded. The swinging felt more fluid and natural in the first game, just slow. In MSM2 it feels nerfed to force the player into using the gimmicks like the boosts and webwings, it just didn't click with me like MSMR's traversal but that could just be a me issue. Then again I play as Spider-Man to swing on webs, not fly like Rico from Just Cause. 
Combat has a lot more depth, but way worse gadgets. I suspect it's to force the player to play with the new shiny toy powers instead, but the symbiotes make the combat feel like something glitched with how un-fun they are to fight.

As for everything else? The sidequests... exist? Nothing much to say about them outside of what they did to Yuri and how they ruined her. Costume's are just terrible and suffer from MCU syndrome of being way too overdesigned. Thank you modders for giving me actual decent options including porting over the first game's costumes. And as for performance? I haven't talked about it simply because it's THE most documented thing about this port. But the complaints are legit. Even my decent PC suffered from moments of freezing. 

So that's my experience with MSM2. A game with solid bones, but missing the rest of the anatomy.

It gets the big things right, but a bunch of things are holding it back.

The port is still very inconsistent. There's gotta be some kind of VRAM leak, because the longer you play, the more it uses. Sometimes, the frame pacing has a good streak (framegen probably helped with this) even when my overlay says I'm using 2.5GB more than my capacity.... There was a point where I turned all settings to low/no RT, at 4K, and it was still using 14GB VRAM. That's lunacy. The longer you play, the more the frame times tend to deviate. 

The game does look better than the first one, but it's not worth the steep hardware price. Other games are being made today that look and run much better.

Did Insomniac just forget about keeping their identities a secret after a while? Too many instances to list for this issue.

I can see an argument being made that this game's world-building leans on identity politics too much. Miles has a questline where he has to find stolen musical instruments, and it just kills the plot for a while. Beautiful new york inspired 3D painting which you run on top of doing activities in a manner either to your taste or not.

* Great looking background visuals.
* Strange looking characters, as if the publisher lost the IP to the comic character art.
* Same 2-3 mob group spawning over and over in different parts of the map, be it radiant events (rendom generated filler mobs to slow you down) or part of the main quests. Same thing over and over for the most part. Recycle, Repeat.
* Dialog written by retired corporate accountants. Bland, tedious attempts at infantile quips, about nothing. Not even attempts at jokes. Nothing to make you even bend that corner of the mouth in "Ah, ok, this was supposed to be funny". Or "I see, this was supposed to be serious" for that matter.
* Forced to go into a menu to skip the poorly written tripe, [b]each time[/b].
* Lots of QTE events. But on a positive note, there's a setting for just holding down a button for [i]some[/i] of them to save the controller from wearing out.
* Combat controls of the kind press A + LB + pause for 123 ms, then press LT + up, touch your nose and cross your eyes while repeating "She sells sea-shells on the sea-shore, the shells she sells are surely sea-shells" and then press Y + X in a very specific timed interval to throw anything but a straight punch.
* If you crave being stuck behind scripted avatars that go on and on about nothing for 5-10 minutes at a time, dragging their feet at snails pace while you're locked into following them, not able to run past them or away from them, then check, this product has you covered in abundance.

Perhaps it's a sandbox that's supposed to be played with muted audio and your own background music in very short increments of 15 minutes per week, assuming you have a gopher memory, so you forget you already played the same loop before. That way the repetition might be less of an issue or at least less in-your-face.

Not a title resonating for me. But if you appreciate the above core pillars and mechanisms making up the title, then it may be for you.

Now go read some other reviews as well, and [i]then[/i] make your [i]own[/i] synthesized purchase decision.

One of the best FSR Frame Gen implementations I've ever seen, very little ghosting. Unfortunately the game is also kind of unplayable without it. Running on an RX 6750XT, Ryzen 5 5600x, 32GB of ram, and an m.2 SSD. Basically slightly higher spec then the PS5, and yet the frame rate tanks to 45-50 fps when swinging/flying around. And the performance gets even worse in the second half of the game. especially when fighting Symbiote enemies.

 The Screenspace implementation is pretty bad, and it has no cubemap refections to fallback on when ratracing is disabled like in previous games, leading to glass reflections actually looking worse then they did in the first game. 
Water reflections seem to be entirely broken. It constantly reflects stuff it shouldn't reflect, or will reflect your character even though you are way to far away to actually cast a reflection, and has a massive gap around your character when swinging over things. So essentially, reflections are super broken if you don't use raytracing, and if you're using a pre 7000 series AMD card, you are kind of forced to. Which is kind of ridiculous in this scenario seeing as the PS5 uses an AMD GPU (equivalent ish to a RX 6600).

Cannot recommend unless it's on sale.
